body.p: (Private)
Rev and Dear Friend

I have delayed send
-ing you the enclosed letter till now
when I have the happiness to trans-
-mit you an order for two copies of
your Bible—the small edition $2. a copy.
I think can dispose of at least four
other copies if you have them for sale
A Christian gentleman—a particular
friend desires one of the two copies and
the other I wish for myself having hither
-to used my dear friend's Geo A Dr. copy.

If you would like me to dispose
of ½ doz copies I think I can without
trouble.

Since writing you previously
Dr Wise has paid a visit here enroute
for Baltimore. He spent four days inclu
-ding Sabbath and Sunday. On the former
he delivered a discourse in German be-
-fore the Anslu Chesed Kahal and on the
latter Sunday morning one before ours the
“Tifereth Israel” in English. I heard the
latter. Its subject was “Judaism its princi-
-ples” His text was taken from Isaiah
He defined Judaism under four heads.
1st A belief in One God
2nd Man was created in the image of God

3rd Since man was created in the image of God
he should endeavor to walk in his ways & imi-
tate his perfection.

4th The Coming Messiah. The fulfilment of the
covenant would be the messianic period.
He denied a personal messiah said the fulfill
-ment of the covenant would be the general
perfection of mankind—nay the complete re-
generation of man—when all the world would
embrace Judaism believe in but One God
and have but one Religion. In a word
that the Jews were to be the messiahs as they
were the a nation of priests they would in
the fullness of time bring all mankind to
their belief and thus redeem the world
&c &c in the same train.

Both the congregations here being orthodox
here took many exceptions as you may sup
-pose to his remarks—nay I think it safe
to say—the mass differed widely with
him—but that would not signify much
perhaps, considering the components of the mass
However I heard a number of highly intelli
-gent Jews express their dissent in terms
not at all complimentary to the Rev Dr.

He made little or no impression other
than by his presence securing additional
subscrition to the Israelite and collecting
from delinquents—in both of which I learn
he was quite successful. You know the
object of his visit to Baltimore—from there
he goes to N. Y. to attend the August meeting
of the Con G. Lodge JOBB.

I am devoting much of
my leisure to the study of our history and religion
limited indeed are the sources from whence
I can derive the information my mind seeks
my thirst craves. I realize fully the value
of your opening editorial Vol V No 1. “De-
mand for Education.” the Mishna Talmud
and Posekin? are indeed sealed books to
me. I would study the Chaldaic tongue
but can find no teacher and being but an in
different Hebrew Scholar I make little
progress. However I do not despair. The Pen
-tatuech and Prophets are the source of
unalloyed enjoyment though I often very
often am at a loss and pray for a commenta
-tor. I trust you will be able to dis-
-cuss the question propounded in my letter
of the 9th in your October number I shall
forward to it with anxiety.

The recent triumph of Judaism in England
is looked upon by Dr Wise as another evidence
of the emancipation of Israel and their growing
importance. He says “this is another evidence
of the growing intelligence of mankind—our
people are being redeemed from the Heralldom?
of ages and in due time willcome to be
regarded as the God of Israel intended they
should be. They will be a nation of priests in
truth and will lead the world up to God
through the faith of Abraham “&c

Pardon me for intruding at
such length upon your valuable time with by
my deultory correspondence and
with renewed wishes of good health
believe me most truly
your friend

My dear wife & all your friends here
desire their affectionate regards.

I enclose a brief paragraph for publi-
cation (if not too late) in Sept No.
